And Barbara, we need to let you go, I know, but I did want to ask you about that part of it, you know, what David was just talking about, the idea that, you know, well, the people who stay on, there's one part of it says, you know, hey, I'm part of the - they didn't - they wanted to keep me.

One thing that he said which struck me was this idea of working harder, which you do get; people are suddenly afraid of being next.

But in reporting this story for Time.com, you know, one of the things that I came across a couple times is just because people are worker and putting in more hours, it doesn't necessarily mean that they're getting more done because of the anxiety and the stress.

It sounded like he was very happy to be talking about it, which is the advice I would pass along from the folks I interviewed, which is, this is a part of - part of the economy that we're in right now, and you might feel awful to complain, to feel bad because you have a job and the person that used to sit right next to you no longer does.
But that doesn't mean that what you're feeling isn't valid.
I mean, there's plenty of, you know, bad feeling and pain to go around in this economy.
So, you know, talking to your coworkers and your family and whoever else, you know, you talk to in life about this I think helps a lot.
At the end of the one of the interviews I did for this story with a layoffs survivor, you know, she just sort of paused a moment and then said, I almost feel better.
She said, that's amazing; I didn't know I had this much to say about this topic.
Well...
One of the things that I've seen in organizations post-downsizing is when very tough executives walk in front of the workforce and say, hey, these are tough times; it hurt me to make the cuts.
That shocks employees.
That stuns employees.
They've never heard their tough, senior executives acknowledge their own personal loss.

And Neal, I've got to tell you, I've been in the boardroom when senior executives have planned the cuts, and with very few exceptions, this is tough for even the most senior and high-powered executives.
It's one thing for them to lay someone off because that person did not do their job well.
It's quite another thing to lay someone off for no fault of their own.
And I've seen the senior people actually shed tears over the fact that they have to do something to a workforce that's not the fault of the workforce.
And if you talk to psychologists, they - any kind of life stressful situation, they say, go to a therapist, talk to your bartender, talk to anyone, but the problem is people do turn inward.
A small but growing number of companies are having what's called venting meetings, where employees come together after the cuts and talk about what happened.
And what I - in my research, I found that even the people who don't speak up benefit from these because they leave the room saying, wow, other people are feeling the exact same way I am.
And you know, in the venting meetings, it's not just about just complaining and griping, because what I find in these sessions, when I facilitate them, they last about an hour.
After about 45 minutes, people are talked out, so what's next.
Then you talk about, what are you going to do differently?
How are you going to walk out of the room and either perceptually change your attitudes, or behaviorally what are you going to change about work?
Because something does have to change.
You just can't go back to your job and do the same old thing.
Unfortunately, there's many pressures at the workplace that just eliminate the opportunity to stop and think about how to do things differently.

This, an email from Dennis: I've survived the 14 downsizing.
The company does the downsizing it's in a respectful way, offering good severance package and unemployment services.

However, management has done poorly in two ways: One, managers themselves have not been downsized in the same proportion; two, managers do not acknowledge the loss the surviving employees feel when their friends are terminated.
It's not survivor guilt, as that's beyond our control, but a sense of loss that managers do not want to acknowledge.
And there's - I think, Mitchell Lee Marks, I think there are plenty of examples of places that do plan the downsizing pretty carefully, but then don't deal with the aftermath.
Yes.
First of all, your emailer is spot on.
How the cuts are made and whether they're shared at the top influences the survivor's reaction.
You know, it's one thing for a CEO to get out there and talk about tough times, but not cut his budget or his perks or his senior team or whatever.
The other thing about acknowledging loss that the emailer said, this is the starting point for going forward and working with the survivors.
You've got to talk about the human psychological side of the downsizing.
You cannot come out here with the macho when-the-going-gets-tough-the-tough-get-going attitude.
(SOUNDBITE OF ""THE SIMPSONS"" THEME SONG)
So, getting in front of people and just putting on the table, this is a difficult experience, is part of it.
And sometimes you do that face to face by a senior executive going in front of people.
Some companies are doing workshops, where they get large groups of people to talk about just the psychology of downsizing and recovery.
And I've worked with a few firms that have done some really creative things.

I worked with a telecom company that there was just so much anger, so much frustration, not only were there cuts, but after the cuts, they merged two divisions that had been internally very competitive.
And so the new coworkers hate - literally hated each other.
There is no better word; they hated each other.
So, what we did is we decided we had to do more than just talk into lecturing with these people.
We had to get there at their emotional level.
So, what we did is we had just a basic workshop, then in the middle of the workshop, I announced to - there are about 40 managers there.
And I said, go to your office and get a memento of your last few years of working here.
Then we brought them all outside and there was a coffin waiting.
And there was a band playing a funeral march.
And we asked the 40 managers one by one to walk up and put their memento.
It was a coffee mug or some letterhead or an award they had, and they had to put it in the coffin.
And then out of the blue around the corner came a 100-ton paver.
And the band then lurched into ""On, Wisconsin,"" you know, that really up-beat fight song...
Sure.

And the group went from being morbid to just cheering and excited and watching the coffin getting smashed by the paver, and then we rushed them inside put them in caps and gowns, and we had the most mundane graduation ceremony you could imagine.
And the CEO came in and said, you're the leaders of the future.
He gave them a gift of a share of company shock as a symbolic gesture, but the point is we've got to bury the old and we've got to graduate to the new.
And in this particular - and this was a very conservative company.
But this shocked people.
What it really did, Neal, in addition to just on an emotional level showing people they had to change, we're saying, hey, leadership is changing.
My gosh, our white-shirt, buttoned-down leadership, for the first time ever, is doing something crazy like having a coffin in the parking lot.
